climbs.name: Zarmog the Dragon Man
climbs.fa: Jim Wilson and Bill Squires, January 1974

content.description: Due to rope drag, this is best done in two pitches.  For the first pitch, climb an offwidth on the right or a 5.9+ finger/hand crack on the left.  The second pitch goes up a hand crack (crux) to a good rest, and then up a slightly overhanging finger crack to the top.
content.protection: Mainly finger to hand size protection.
content.location: This route is located roughly in the middle of the south face of the rock.  Two parallel cracks go up the lower tier of the rock, with a straight-in hand crack above.

climbs.name: Quivering Lips
climbs.fa: Matt Cox, Dave Evans, Gary Ayers, Spencer and Allan Lennard, November 1974

content.description: The route starts out with a fun mantle.  Then you have straightforward, well-protected jamming to the top.
content.location: This is a vertical crack in a large dihedral.  It starts from a large ledge, near the left end of the south face.

content.description: A couple of thin steep  moves lead to the knobby face section which eases considerably.
content.protection: Three bolts, and a two bolt anchor, hangers (one an old Leeper I think) but no chain.
content.location:
Around the corner to the left of the arete of the leftmost block of

North Horror Rock (West Face), Joshua Tree NP  A. Lippo Suction (5.10a) B. Face Lift (5.11c) C. Quivering Lips (5.8) D. Lip Sync (5.11b) E. Zarmog the Dragon Man (5.10a) F. The Ice Experience (5.9) G. Ungawaa (5.11a)

. Scramble up the slab, a little exposed.

climbs.name: Face Lift
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Tommy Romero, November 1995

content.description: A short but technical arete to test your face-climbing prowess. Two stars out of five.
content.protection: 4 bolts, anchors set back from edge (walk-off descent)
content.location:
Northwest arete of the block with

Lippo Suction

- it's just around the corner from that route.
